subdebate.1.para: Details of some of the more important factors affecting the expenditure of departments are set out below: -

Treasury. - The integration of the statistical services of New South Wales, South Australia and Western Australia with the Bureau of Census and Statistics involves additional administrative costs estimated at £306,000 for the year. Much of this additional Commonwealth expenditure will relieve the Budgets of the States concerned.

Interior. - The main increases this year are in respect of the printing of electoral rolls (£93,000) and the provision of an additional £129,000 for instruments and apparatus for the Meteorological Branch.

Civil Aviation. - The development vote this year is £386,000 higher than last year, mainly because of a larger cash contribution to the cost of ground facilities in the Pacific. An estimated increase of £405,000 in expenditure on the maintenance and operation of civil aviation facilities is required mainly to overcome a back-log of essential aerodrome resealing work. There has also been some increase in the charge for meteorological services.
Health. - There has been a general increase in activities of the Department.
Trade. - The increase reflects some expansion in the work of the Department and in the commercial intelligence services abroad.
Territories. - The increase reflects the recruitment of additional staff to cope with increased activity in the Northern Territory and in Papua and New Guinea.
National Development. - Additional amounts are required for an oil drilling programme in Western Australia and for aerial photography.

Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization. - The increase includes provision for the recruitment of additional staff in 1957-58, more extensive rain-making experiments, and more equipment.

Atomic Energy Commission. - The increase of £712,000 is due almost wholly to the commencement in 1957-58 of operations of the experimental atomic reactor and associated research laboratories at Lucas Heights.

Cotton Bounty. - Under the Cotton Bounty Act 1951-57 a bounty is payable on seed cotton delivered by growers to processors up to 31st December, 1958, The rate of bounty is designed to give growers an average return of 14d. per lb., and under an amendment made earlier this year interim payments of bounty can be made. As the 1957 crop is expected to be smaller and of higher quality than that of the previous year, 1957-58 bounty payments are estimated to be lower than in 1956-57.

Tractor Bounty. - The Tractor Bounty Act 1939-56 provides for the payment of bounty on wheel-type tractors produced in Australia during the three years commencing 24th October, 1955. The bounty rates vary from £80 to £240 per tractor according to the horse-power and the proportion of Australian materials used. The Act was amended in 1956 to extend the bounty to larger tractors (those falling within the 55-70 horse-power range). Expenditure of £158,000 in 1956-57 was high because it included retrospective payments of bounty in respect of these larger tractors for about eight months of the previous year. Expenditure in 1957-58 is estimated to remain at about the same level because of an expected increase in production and of the operation for a full year of the amendment of the Act.

Sulphuric Acid Bounty. - The Sulphuric Acid Bounty Act 1954-57 and Regulations thereunder provide for the payment of a bounty on sulphuric acid produced in Australia from indigenous pyrites and lead sinter gas, during the five years from 1st July, 1954. The rate of bounty is £2 per ton when the landed cost of imported brimstone is £20 10s. per ton and rises or falls by ls. 9d. for each 5s. by which the landed cost of brimstone is below or above £20 10s. per ton. It is estimated that expenditure in 1957-58 will be £79,000 higher than in 1956-57, partly because production should be higher in 1957-58 and partly because the bounty has recently been extended to acid produced from lead sinter gas.

Gold-Mining Industry Assistance. - Under the Gold-Mining Industry Assistance Act 1954-56, a subsidy is payable under certain conditions on gold produced during the five years ending 30th June, 1959. Small producers (those with an annual output of less than 500 ounces) receive a flat rate of subsidy of £1 10s. per ounce. Large producers are paid at a rate equal to three-quarters of the amount by which their cost of production exceeds £13 10s. per ounce, with a subsidy limit of £2 per ounce. Under the proposed amendments to the Act these rates will be increased to £2 per ounce for small producers and a maximum of £2 15s. per ounce for large producers. With these amendments, the estimated expenditure of £600,000 in 1957-58 is £105,000 greater than in 1956-57.

Flax Fibre Bounty. - The Flax Fibre Bounty Act 1954-57 authorizes the payment of a bounty on flax fibre produced in Australia up to 31st October, 1957. The rate of bounty varies inversely with movements in the landed cost of imported flax fibre and is calculated, subject to limits, to give producers a return of £365 per ton. Bounty expenditure in 1957-58 up to 31st October, 1957, when the present Act expires is estimated at £60,000. (The bulk of the bounty payments is made in the early months of the financial year.) The higher estimated expenditure in 1957-58 is attributable to the lower landed cost of imported fibre.

Rayon Yam Bounty. - The Rayon Yarn Bounty Act 1954-56 provides for payment of a bounty of 6d. per lb. on continuous filament acetate rayon yarn produced and sold in Australia up to 30th June, 1959. Estimated expenditure in 1957-58 of £100,000 is £40,000 higher than actual expenditure in 1956-57 because of an expected increase in production.

Cellulose Acetate Flake Bounty. - The Cellulose Acetate Flake Bounty Act 1956 authorizes payment of a bounty of lOd. per lb. on cellulose acetate flake produced in Australia and sold for local use during the three-year period commencing 1st July, 1955. It is estimated that payments under this Act will be £140,000 in 1957-58. This estimate, although allowing for increased production, is £39,000 lower than actual expenditure in 1956- 57 which included a large retrospective payment in respect of 1955-56.

Dairy Products Bounty. - The Dairying Industry Act 1957 provides for the payment of a bounty on butter and cheese for a further period of five years from 1st July, 1957. The payment of bounty ensures that, in respect of butter and cheese consumed in Australia plus 20 per cent, of those quantities, dairy-farmers receive a return based on the cost of efficient production as determined annually. Expenditure on the bounty in 1956-57 was £13,500,000. The same provision is made for

Prime Minister's Department. - The estimates for this year includes £100,000 for the remaining expenditure on the Olympic Games compared with £575,000 provided last year. Provision for flood relief is £202,000 less than actual expenditure in 1956-57. As against these reductions, it is expected that the grant to the Australian National University will increase from £640,000 to £852,000, and that expenditure on the Commonwealth scholarship scheme will increase from £1,190,000 to £1,270,000 mainly on account of the proposed increase in allowances under the scheme.

Department of External Affairs. - Expenditure last year included an advance to the United Nations of £449,000 towards the cost of clearing the Suez Canal. On the other hand, expenditure this year on the Antarctic Research Expedition is expected to be somewhat higher.

International Development and Relief. - An amount of £5,245,000 has been provided this year for expenditure under the Colombo Plan. (Expenditure last year amounted to £5,038,000.) Of this amount £3,945,000 is in respect of economic development and £1,300,000 is for technical assistance. Provision has also been made for Australia's contributions to United Nations Technical Assistance and United Nations International Children's Fund (£475,000), United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East (£50,000), United Nations Refugees' Emergency Fund (£50,000), International Red Cross (£5,000), and Relief for Hungarian Refugees (£25,000).

Department of the Treasury. - Refunds and remissions of taxes and fines are estimated at £270,000 this year compared with £215,000 last year. Expenditure on a Census of retail establishments is estimated at £50,000 as against only £3,000 in 1956-57.
Department of Health. - The grant for cattle tick eradication in New South Wales of £570,000 this year is £105,000 lower than last year.
Department of Trade. - The provision for trade publicity is £410,000 as compared with £320,000 in 1956-57.

Department of Social Services. - The increase is almost wholly in respect of financial assistance for the building of homes for the aged. At present, the Government is contributing on a £1 for £1 basis with approved organizations towards the capital cost of building homes for the aged. It is now proposed to double the Commonwealth's contribution to £2 for each £1 contributed by such organizations. The provision for this year is £1,800,000 compared with actual expenditure of £751,000 in 1956-57.

Department of Shipping and Transport. - The shipbuilding subsidy vote is £421,000 higher this year and reflects a higher rate of ship construction, and the placing of more orders under the increased subsidy rate of 33J per cent, of cost. Of the other items under this head, increased provision is required to meet the cost of the coastal radio service and demolition of a dual-purpose jetty at Townsville. These increases are offset by a reduction in the Tasmanian shipping subsidy and the Papua-New Guinea shipping subsidy, which ends this year.

Department of National Development. - Last year's expenditure included an amount of £175,000 for compensation for cancellation of open-cut coal-mining contracts. This year'sexpenditure includes an amount of £300,000 for deep stratigraphic drilling for oil.

Department of Immigration. - Expenditure on immigration in 1957-58 is estimated at £1,450,000- higher than in 1956-57 because of an increase in the number of assisted British migrants and in the cost of sea passages for British migrants.

Subscriptions to Various Organizations. - Last year's expenditure included subscriptions paid to the International Finance Corporation, the International Bank and the Export Payments Insurance Corporation. These subscriptions totalled in all £2,463,000. No provision is made in the estimates for payments of this nature in 1957-58.

Public Service Pensions and Retiring Allowances. - The Government contribution to the Superannuation Fund is estimated at £2,255,000 in 1957- 58, an increase of £681,000 on the amount paid last year. The increased provision in 1957-58 as compared with expenditure in 1956-57 is partly due to the re-payment from the Fund in 1956-57 of an amount of £251,000 under Section 11 of the Superannuation Act in respect of interest on investments, and in part reflects the normal increase in Commonwealth contribution and the proposed increases in certain rates of superannuation.

Public Debt Charges. - Included under this item are all debt charges other than those on Commonwealth war debt and on works debt in respect of Business Undertakings and Territories. The increase represents mainly increased interest subsidy to the States on housing advances under the CommonwealthState Housing Agreement. The Commonwealth recovers from the States interest at the rate of 3 per cent, on advances made in each year up to and including 1955-56 and 4 per cent, on advances made in 1956-57 and subsequently. However, maturing loans have been converted into higher interest bearing securities so that the difference between the rate of interest paid by the Commonwealth on borrowings for State housing and the rate of interest recovered from the States has tended to widen. Interest on International Bank loans is also estimated to increase to £5,195,000 this year compared with £4,986,000 in 1956-57 due to an increase in the total amount drawn.

Wool Research.- The provision of £990,000 represents the Commonwealth's contribution to the Wool Research Trust Fund in accordance with the Wool Research Act 1957. During 1956-57 the Commonwealth contributed £489,000 to wool research under provisions of the Wool Use Promotion Act which have been repealed.

Special Payment to National Debt Sinking Fund. - In 1956-57, an amount of £700,000 was paid to Sinking Fund from Consolidated Revenue. A similar amount had been paid to Revenue from the Enemy Subjects Trust Account out of the proceeds of German enemy assets acquired under the Reparations Agreement. No provision is made for any similar payments in 1957-58.

Other. - This item includes Parliamentary Allowances and other statutory payments of salaries and allowances, and contributions under the Australian National University Act and the Fishing Industry Act.

Railways. - The increase of £631,000 is mainly in salaries and wages, and reflects the employment of more labour to handle increased traffic and to give concentrated attention to maintenance of the permanent way, including re-sleepering, repairs to bridges and other structures. It is expected that the increased expenditure will be offset by extra revenue from additional traffic.

Post Office. - Total expenditure is expected to increase by £6,888,000 in 1957-58. Wages and salaries are expected to cost £4,934,000 more than last year, because of wage increases and additional staff to handle extra traffic. Higher prices and increased quantities are expected to increase the cost of stores and materials by £736,000. Provision for general expenses has been increased by £1,149,000 mainly because of more vehicles and units of plant to be maintained, higher fares and travelling allowances and increased provision for superannuation pensions and printing of directories. The provision for debt charges is £231,000 below last year's expenditure because some loans have been redeemed.

Broadcasting and Television. - Most of the estimated increase of £675,000 is due to increased expenditure on television which commenced in 1956-57 and will operate for a full year in 1957-58. (An amount of £1,553,000 is included for expenditure on television in 1957-58 compared with expenditure last year of £923,000.) The cost of servicing additional broadcasting stations in country areas will also contribute to the higher expenditure.

Northern Territory. - The estimated increase of £897,000 in expenditure in the Northern Territory includes an additional £212,000 for aboriginal welfare and a further £223,000 for salaries. Increased expenditure is also envisaged in 1957-58 on educational and health services and in respect of the subsidy to the Darwin Municipal Council.

Australian Capital Territory. - Expenditure under this head is expected to rise in 1957-58 by £242,000 mainly because of increased expenditure on repairs and maintenance and on health and educational services.

Papua and New Guinea. - Practically the whole of this expenditure takes the form of a grant by the Commonwealth to the Administration of the Territory of Papua and New Guinea to meet the deficiency between local revenue and expenditure in the Territory. Expenditure in 1957-58 is expected to exceed that in 1956-57 by £1,685,000 mainly because of increased expenditure on health and educational services, repairs and maintenance, residential accommodation and roads and bridges.

Tax Reimbursement Grants Determined under Formula. - Under the States Grants (Tax Reimbursement) Act 1946-1948 the tax reimbursement grants were fixed at a total of £40,000,000 in 1946-47 and £45,000,000 in 1947-48, while in respect of subsequent years the Act provides for the aggregate grant of £45,000,000 to be varied in accordance with a formula which takes account of:-

item.label: (a)
item.para: variations in the States' populations since 1st July, 1947; and

item.label: (b)
item.para: the percentage increase in the level of average wages per person employed over the level of 1945-46.

subdebate.1.para: Prior to 1957-58 the grant was distributed among the States partly in proportion to the distribution in 1947-48 and partly in proportion to the States' populations as adjusted for numbers of school children and for relative sparsity of population. In 1957-58, and each subsequent year, the whole of the tax reimbursement grant will be distributed in proportion to the States' adjusted populations.

The amount paid to the States in 1956-57 in accordance with the formula was £154,645,000 while it is estimated that the amount payable under the formula in 1957-58 will be £166,200,000. The estimated grants payable to individual States in 1957-58 and the grants paid in the six previous years are compared below: -

The tax reimbursement grant payable to each State: in each year is reduced by the amount of any arrears of State income taxation which may be received in that year by the State. In 1956-57 these arrears amounted to £23,084.

Supplementary Grants. - In- 1949-50 and each subsequent year payments have been made by the Commonwealth to supplement the grants determined under the tax reimbursement formula. The. following table shows the actual payments made in each year since 1949-50 together with the estimated- payments in 1957-58.

At a Premiers" Conference held in May, 1957', the Commonwealth-, agreed to: make available to the; States, a- special financial assistance grant sufficient to bring the- total payment for. 1957-58 to £190,000,000: As the amount payable in- 1957.-58 under the tax reimbursement formula is estimated at £166,200,000 this, involves a supplementary grant of approximately £23,800,000. The whole, of this, supplementary- grant, will be- distributed among, the States in the. same- way as the formula grant for 195.7-58..
The total payments of the reimbursement and supplementary grants to individual States in each of the last, six years and the estimated payments, in 1957-58 are shown in the table below: -

Special Grants. - Special grants have been paid annually by the Commonwealth to. Western Australia since 1.910, to Tasmania since 1912 and to South Australia since 1929. Since the establishment of the Commonwealth Grants Commission in 1933', the special grants paid each year to these
States have been the subject of recommendations by the Commission.
The special grants paid to the States during the last six years, together with the grants recommended by- the Grants Commission for payment in 1957-58, are shown in the following table: -

Payments under Financial Agreement. - Under the Financial Agreement, which was entered into by the Commonwealth and the States in 1927, the Commonwealth agreed to contribute certain amounts towards meeting the interest and sinking fund payments in respect of the States' debts.

The Agreement provides that the Commonwealth will in each year during the period of 58 years commencing on 1st July, 1927, contribute a fixed amount of £7,584,912 towards the interest payable on the States' debts. This amount is distributed among the States as follows: -

The sinking fund contributions made by the Commonwealth in respect of the States' debts vary according to the nature of the borrowings. The Commonwealth contributions in respect of sinking fund on States' debts are paid direct to the National Debt Sinking Fund. In 1956-57 these contributions amounted to £4,640,043, while the contributions in 1957-58 are estimated at £5,045,088.

Commonwealth Aid Roads. - Payments under this scheme are governed by the provisions of the Commonwealth Aid Roads Act 1954-1956. The 1954 legislation, which replaced the Commonwealth Aid Roads Act 1950, increased the allocations from Petrol Tax for roads purposes from 6d. a gallon on imported petrol and 3 id. a gallon on locally refined petrol to 7d. a gallon on both imported and locally refined petrol (excluding aviation spirit). The legislation also provided for an increase from 35 per cent, to 40 per cent, in the minimum proportion of the allocations to be spent on rural roads and an increase from £500,000 to £800,000 per annum in the amount set aside for strategic roads, roads of access to Commonwealth property and other roads serving Commonwealth purposes.

The legislation was amended on two occasions during 1955-56. The first of these amendments provided for the amount set aside from the total roads allocations for road safety purposes to be increased from £100,000 to £150,000 per annum. A second amendment increased the allocations from Petrol Tax for roads purposes from 7d. a gallon to 8d. a gallon on both imported and locally refined petrol (excluding aviation spirit). This amendment took effect as from 1st April, 1956.
The estimated allocations for Commonwealth Aid Roads purposes in 1957-58, compared with actual allocations in 1956-57, are as follows: -

The Commonwealth Aid Roads grants received by each of the States in recent years are compared below with the estimated grants for 1957-58. These figures exclude the amounts set aside each year for strategic roads and road safety.

Commonwealth Aid Roads - Special Assistance. - Legislation will be introduced shortly to authorize a special allocation for roads purposes of £3,000,000 in the current financial year and also in 1958-59. To help finance this special allocation, which will be additional to the funds provided under the Commonwealth Aid Roads Act 1954-1956, it is proposed to impose a tax on automotive diesel oil consumed by road users.

Western Australian Waterworks Grant. - Under the Western Australian Grant (Water Supply) Act 1948-1955 the Commonwealth is, within specified limits, assisting the State of Western Australia to finance the cost of constructing the Comprehensive Water Supply Scheme. The scheme involves the reticulation of water to townships and homesteads in a wheat belt area of about 4,000,000 acres inland from Perth; reticulation of water to towns along the Great Southern Railway from Beverley to Katanning; and increasing the supply of water to the Eastern Goldfields area of the State. During 1956-57 payments to Western Australia under this legislation amounted to £462,500, bringing total payments by the Commonwealth in respect of the Scheme up to £2,612,500.

It is proposed to amend the Act to remove the limits on the annual contributions by the Commonwealth towards the cost of the Scheme and also to increase the aggregate limit of those contributions from £4,000,000 to £5,000,000. It is estimated that payments to the State in 1957-58 will amount to £572,000. Payments in each year since the inception of the arrangements are set out below: -

Encouragement of Meat Production. - As a means of stimulating pastoral development, the provision of new and improved facilities for the movement of cattle both by road and stock route is proceeding in the channel country of southwest Queensland and in the area serving the meatworks at Wyndham, Western Australia. The Governments of Queensland and Western Australia are responsible for the constructional work within their respective States, and Commonwealth financial assistance is being afforded them in accordance with the States Grants (Encouragement of Meat Production) Act 1949-1954. Payments under the Act are estimated at £127,000 in 1957-58 as compared with £134,000 in 1956-57.
The distribution of the grants in each year since their commencement in 1950-51 is shown below: -

Mental Institutions - Contribution to Capital Expenditure. - In 1955 the Commonwealth agreed to provide financial assistance of up to £10,000,000 towards capital expenditure incurred by the States on mental institutions. The Commonwealth offered to pay £1 for every £2 spent by the States. Expenditure by the Commonwealth in 1956-57 amounted to £1,248,000 and brought total Commonwealth expenditure under the scheme to £2,021,000. The estimated expenditure in 1957-58 is £1,450,000.
The following table shows the actual payments to each State under the scheme in the last two years and the estimated payments in 1957-58: -

Tuberculosis Hospitals - Reimbursement of Capital Expenditure. - Under the Tuberculosis Act 1948 the Commonwealth undertook to reimburse the States for capital expenditure on buildings, furnishings, equipment and plant for the diagnosis, treatment and control of tuberculosis. In 1957-58 expenditure is expected to total £2,550,000, being the amount the States are likely to claim during the year in reimbursement of their expenditure on approved capital items. Expenditure in 1956-57 was £2,381,000.
The distribution of Commonwealth grants under the Tuberculosis Act 1948 in recent years is shown in the table below: -

Coal Mining Industry - Long Service Leave. - In the States where coal-miners have been awarded long service leave by industrial tribunals the State governments agreed to reimburse employers the costs they incur in granting this leave. The Commonwealth in turn agreed to reimburse the States the amounts paid and the administrative costs incurred by the States in giving effect to these arrangements. To provide the funds required for these purposes an excise was imposed on coal under the Coal Excise Act 1949. An amount equivalent to the proceeds of the excise is appro priated to a Trust Account under the States Grants (Coal Mining Industry Long Service Leave) Act 1945-1956. The appropriation is estimated at £609,000 in 1957-58 compared with actual expenditure of £597,000 in 1956-57.

The amounts of excise collections credited to the Coal Mining Industry Long Service Leave Fund in respect of individual States in each of the last six years, and the estimated credits to the Fund for those States in 1957-58, are -compared in the table below: -

States Grants - Imported Houses. - Under the States Grants (Imported Houses) Act 1950 the Commonwealth provided for the payment to the States of a subsidy on imported prefabricated houses of up -to £300 a house. Expenditure to 30th June, 19.57, amounted to £4,193,000, and it is estimated that the provision of £1,000 in 1957-58 will complete the scheme.

subdebateinfo.title: Financial Assistance for Universities. - The States

subdebate.1.para: Grants (Universities) Act 1957 authorizes the Commonwealth to make grants to the States for university purposes of up to £2,300,000 in each of the calendar years 1957 and 1958. Expenditure in the financial year 1957-58 is estimated at £2,300,000, compared with £2,262,000 in 1956-57.
The estimated grants to individual States in 1957-58 are compared with the actual grants paid in recent years in the following table: -

Port Pirie Railway. - Under the Port Augusta to Port Pirie Railway Act 1935-1950 the Commonwealth agreed to pay £20,000 per annum for twenty years as a contribution towards the expenses incurred by the South Australian Government in building the railway from Port Augusta to Port Pirie. The agreement expired at the end of 1956-57.
Items the estimates for which show major variation from expenditure in 1956-57 are -
Treasury. - Additional expenditure by the Government Printing Office on plant and machinery mainly accounts for the increased provision of £104,000.
Attorney-General's. - The additional provision relates to the construction of the new Arbitration Court building in Melbourne.
Interior. - The increase of £441,000 is in respect of buildings for Commonwealth offices in Melbourne and Canberra.
Works. - The provision for plant and equipment is £251,000 greater than actual expenditure last year, against which must be offset reductions in other capital items amounting to £24,000.

Civil Aviation. - The provision of £2,619,000 for works, sites and buildings includes £2,340,000 for the works programme and £279,000 for the acquisition of sites and buildings, and in each case represents some increase over last year's expenditure. The provision of £1,650,000 for technical equipment includes £1,360,000 to be spent against outstanding commitments arising from orders placed in previous years, the balance of £290,000 being for new projects, mainly vehicles and fire-fighting equipment for use on aerodromes. The increase of £270,000 over 1956-57 is mainly accounted for by an uneven incidence of payments on long-term orders.

Capital for Qantas and T.A.A. - This provision covers £1,250,000 for Qantas Empire Airways Limited and £500,000 for the Australian National Airlines Commission (Trans-Australia Airlines). In each case the requirement arises from the general expansion of activities and the obligation placed on both airlines to provide buildings and other ground facilities from their capital funds. The provision for Qantas is £250,000 less than in 1956-57, while in the case of Trans-Australia Airlines the £500,000 represents the first addition to its capital since 1948-49.
Health. - The greater part of the increase is required for the purchase of laboratory equipment for the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories.

Construction of Merchant Ships. - The need for a provision under this heading has disappeared with the establishment of. the Australian Coastal Shipping Commission (see below), which now meets expenditure on new ships being built for its fleet.

Australian Coastal Shipping Commission. - The Commission has operated as a business undertaking since the beginning of 1957, its capital consisting of the value of transferred ships (including expenditure on ships under construction) and some cash funds transferred from the Australian Shipping Board. The programme of new ship construction results in the Commission having significant commitments for future payments, and while these can be met largely from profits and depreciation recoveries, there is a requirement for additional capital from time to time. The provision of £500,000 in 1957-58 is needed to allow the Commission to meet this year's payments in full.

Standardization of Railway Gauges. - This provision relates to work being carried out in South Australia under the 1949 Standardization Agreement. The 1956-57 vote of £400,000 was supplemented by South Australia using in full a working advance of £100,000, total expenditure on the project thus being £500,000. The 1957-58 provision allows for restoration of £50,000 of the working advance, plus an extra £50,000 to allow work to proceed this year at a rate of £550,000.

Christmas Island. - The increased provision for Christmas Island (Indian Ocean) arises from the proposed transfer of sovereignty over the Island to Australia, and from the need to increase the output of phosphate. Australia and New Zealand are sharing equally in both these expenditures.

War Service Homes. - The increase from £30,000,000 last year to £35,000,000 this year will enable more homes to be financed and should mean some reduction in the waiting time for advances and in the number of outstanding applications.

Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Authority. - The greater part of expenditure by the Authority relates to the major contracts - the construction of the Adaminaby Dam, the Eucumbene-Tumut tunnel and the T.l project. Expenditure under these contracts may be lower than last year, but this reduction will be more than offset by increased non-contract expenditure such as on plant and equipment, stores and materials, wages and general expenses.

Expenditure under River Murray Waters Act. - The present programme of the Commission, to which the Commonwealth contributes 25 per cent, of the cost, includes increasing the capacity of the Hume Reservoir from 2,000,000 to 2,500,000 acre feet and the associated removal of the Tallangatta township. The Commonwealth's contribution this year is £575,000 compared with £492,500 for 1956-57.
Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization. - The increased provision is required mainly for new buildings and aircraft for rainmaking experiments.

Australian Atomic Energy Commission. - The increase of £159,000 over actual expenditure in 1956- 57 relates mainly to the research reactor project at Lucas Heights, which is expected to be a complete working establishment by February, 1958. The remainder includes part of the cost of headquarters for the Australian Institute of Nuclear Science and Engineering at Lucas Heights, structural alterations to the Commission's head office, capital equipment at Rum Jungle and plant for use in the search for uranium.

Railways. - The decrease of £305,000 under this head is due to the pending completion of the standard gauge railway from Stirling North to Marree, the 1957-58 provision being £1,035,000 against 1956-57 expenditure of £1,500,000 on this project. However, expenditure on other railways capital works, including new rolling-stock, ballasting of the Trans-Australian, Central and North Australia Railways, new housing and workshop equipment, is estimated to be £2,082,000 in 1957- 58, or £157,000 more than last year.

Post Office. - The vote for technical equipment is to be increased by £2,548,000 to £30,000,000 to enable larger numbers of subscribers' telephone connexions to be installed. Trunk line and telegraph services are also to be improved. The provision for works projects is also increased, by £1,163.000, to £4,000,000, whilst the provision for the acquisition of sites and buildings is slightly reduced.

Broadcasting and Television. - The decrease in expenditure under this head is due to the fact that the bulk of the expenditure on establishing national television in Sydney and Melbourne, which commenced late in 1956, was incurred in 1956-57. Expenditure on television equipment was £1,296,000 in 1956-57 compared with estimated expenditure of £520,000 in 1957-58. Sites and buildings for television cost £763,000 in 1956-57, the estimated expenditure in 1957-58 being £497,000.

Territories. - The increase of £2,867,000 in the provision for the Australian Capital Territory reflects an acceleration of the building programme to provide for the transfer to Canberra of the personnel of the Defence departments. Expenditure in the Northern Territory is also expected to increase with an expansion in building and engineering services and developmental road construction, and in the provision of health facilities.

subdebateinfo.title: Item No. 20. - Loan Consolidation and Investment Reserve

subdebate.1.para: In 1956-57 an amount of £194,793,000 was appropriated from Consolidated Revenue to the Loan Consolidation and Investment Reserve. Of this amount, £83,182,000 was credited to the Reserve as a result of certain Trust Fund transactions. Apart from expenditure from the Reserve on loan repurchases and redemptions, an amount of £96,000,000 was invested from the Reserve in a special loan to assist in financing State works and housing programmes and War Service Land Settlement.

It is necessary to make provision again this year to meet commitments in respect of State works and housing programmes, War Service Land Settlement and debt redemption. An amount of £119,363,000 has been included in the Estimates for appropriation to the Reserve this year.

debate.para: At a meeting in May, 1957, the Loan Council approved a total governmental borrowing programme of £200,000,000 for 1957-58. The Loan Council also approed total borrowing programmes for 1957-58 of £89,000,000 for semi-governmental and local authorities.
The approved governmental programme for 1957-58 compares with the actual programme for last financial year as follows: -

The resolution approving a total governmental borrowing programme of £200,000,000 was supported by the Commonwealth on the understanding that the State Governments would fulfil certain conditions designed to promote governmental loan raisings in 1957-58. On that understanding, the Commonwealth indicated that it would also be prepared to take the following steps to assist that programme: -

item.label: (i)
item.para: To make available to the States the Australian currency equivalent of any new money loans raised overseas:

item.label: (ii)
item.para: to leave to the States for housing and works purposes the whole of the proceeds derived from public loan raisings in Australia;

item.label: (iii)
item.para: To arrange, to the maximum possible extent, for the re-financing of maturing loans that may not be fully converted, and to endeavour to do the same in respect of maturing savings certificates;

item.label: (iv)
item.para: To make monthly advances to the States at an annual rate of £200,000,000 for the first six months of the financial year, the position to be reviewed and the amount of special loan assistance the Commonwealth may provide from its own resources towards the financing of the Loan Council programme for 1957-58 to be tentatively determined not later than 31st January, 1958.

debate.para: In 1956-57, Commonwealth securities redeem able in Australia and totalling £258,500,000 reached their final maturity dates. The amount outstanding at 30th June, 1957, and maturing in 1957-58 is £419,671,000. Details are as follows:-

The securities maturing in August, 1957, and May, 1958, were taken up in cash or conversion loans between May, 1956, and June, 1957, as short-term securities, while the November, 1957, securities (of which £42,000,000 is war debt) were issued mainly hi a cash and conversion loan in October, 1941. Holders of the securities maturing in August, 1957, have already been invited to convert their holdings, the new securities offered being 4 per cent, securities maturing in May, 1959, issued at £99 5s., and 5 per cent, securities maturing in April, 1965, and in April, 1976, issued at par. The same securities were offered in a cash loan which opened on 8th August.
In addition to the securities maturing in Australia, an Australian loan of £Stg.20,090,200 will fall due in London on 15th April, 1958.
Other Loan Commitments in 1957-58.

Apart from its commitments in relation to the Loan Council borrowing programme, and in relation to the financing of redemptions of maturing, loans and of war savings certificates and savings certificates, the Commonwealth will need to find finance in 1957-58 for advances to States in respect of War Service Land Settlement. These advances are estimated at £8,000,000.

The estimated amounts which will be made available by the Commonwealth to individual States in 1957-58 for capital expenditure on War Service Land Settlement and the actual amounts, made available in 1956-57 are as follows: -

subdebate.1.para: The National Welfare Fund Act 1952 requires an appropriation from Consolidated Revenue to the Fund each year of an amount equal to expenditure from the Fund in that year. The increase of £19,736,000 in estimated receipts for 1957-58 reflects an estimated increase in expenditure from the Fund in 1957-58 of £19,649,000 plus an estimated increase of £87,000 in interest received from the investment of the balance in the Fund.

Of the expected increase in expenditure from the National Welfare Fund of £19,649,000 in 1957-58, £9,531,000 is due to the cost in 1957-58 of the proposed increases in social service and health benefits.
The cost of the new proposals in 1957-58 and in a full year are as follows: -
Comments on particular items of expenditure where the estimate for 1957-58 varies substantially from actual expenditure in 1956-57 are set out below: -

Age and Invalid Pensions. - It is estimated that expenditure on age and invalid pensions in 1957-58 will increase by £12,590,000. The proposed increases in pension are estimated to cost £7,500,000 in 1957-58, whilst the balance of the increase (namely, £5,090,000) provides for an increased number of pensioners and for an advance payment of £760,000 to the Post Office in respect of the pension pay-day on 3rd July, 1958.

Widows' Pensions. - Of the estimated increase in expenditure of £1,268,000 on widows' pensions in 1957-58, £630,000 represents the estimated cost of the higher pensions now proposed, whilst the remaining £638,000 allows for an increase in the number of widows entitled to pension and for the full year effect of the concessions granted in widows' pensions in 1956-57.
Child Endowment. - The increased provision of £2,563,000 reflects the growth in the number of children and an increase in the proportion of second and later children.
Unemployment and Sickness Benefits. - The estimated increase of £700,000 is due to the increases proposed in the rates of benefit.

Hospital Benefits. - Expenditure on hospital benefits in 1957-58 is estimated to be £1,117,000 greater than in 1956-57 because of the increase in benefit now proposed and the increase in the number of beneficiaries.

Pharmaceutical Benefits. - The estimated increase of £666,000 is mainly attributable to an increase in the number of prescriptions (£394,000), an increase in the average price of prescriptions (£159,000) and an increase in the payment to hospitals for drugs provided from their dispensaries (£98,000).

Medical Benefits. - Of the estimated increase in expenditure of £380,000 in 1957-58, £354,000 is attributable to a continued growth in the number of persons participating in the Medical Benefits Scheme and £26,000 to the proposed revision of the amounts of certain medical benefits.
Medical Benefits for Pensioners. - The estimated increase in expenditure of £106,000 provides for the greater number of pensioners and their dependants entitled to the benefits.
Pharmaceutical Benefits for Pensioners. - It is estimated that expenditure will rise by £127,000 in 1957-58 because of increases in the average price and number of prescriptions.

talk.start.para: .- I believe that the first important thing that I should say about this trade agreement between Australia and Japan is that, in my opinion, it is vitally necessary. It is in the interests of both countries, and particularly of Australia at the present time. It is of no use to go back 25 years into history, as did the honorable member for Port Adelaide (Mr. Thompson). The important thing is to look at the features of international trade, as we see them in this post war world. If we consider the developments that have taken place, and the way in which nations now trade with each other, we can see that it is important for governments to take a greater interest, and to play a more active part, in international trading. I do not refer to the trade carried on by nations behind the iron curtain by international barter agreements and the like.

speech.para: If we consider the trading that takes place between the nations of the Western world, we shall see how, since World War II., it has been necessary for governments to take a greater interest, and play a more active part, in international trading. We have only to see what has been happening in relation to the formation of the European Common Market to learn how active a part the governments of the European countries comprising the common market are taking in international trade. More important still from the British and Australian stand-point is the role that the United Kingdom is playing in the European Common Market. Whether or not the British like it, Britain will have to take an increasing interest in trade with Europe. Therefore, it is likely that the volume of trade between the United Kingdom and Australia will dwindle, and it will be important for Australia to replace that trade by trade with the nations of Asia. We shall also see how the United States has carried out trade during the last ten years and how the Government of that country has taken a great part in those activities. The way in which the United States has disposed of trade surpluses by international agreement has shown how important it is that a government should play its part. I do not for a moment advocate the policy adopted by the United States with regard to its disposal of surpluses. The United States has also imposed definite quotas on imports and while members opposite, including the honorable member for Port Adelaide (Mr. Thompson), advocate that this Government should impose quotas on imports, I feel that particularly the woollen and worsted manufacturers, who have advocated such a course, would be the first people to criticise the imposition by the United States of quota restrictions on the import of woollen and worsted products. The United States has destroyed any hope that our manufacturers might have had of exporting woollen materials to that country.

If we adopt such a view when the United States imposes restrictions, how can we advocate a similar course of action in this country? While, as a member of the Liberal party, I would always believe in the development of trade internationally being as free as possible, I believe that in this post-war pattern of nation to nation trading, with governments playing an increasing part, if there are rules under which the game of international trade is played, then we must play the game according to those rules. 1 believe there are only two courses open - to have a completely planned economy, which is the one thing we should avoid at all costs, or for government and private enterprise to consult together as much as possible in the development of international trade. The Minister for Trade (Mr. McEwen) in his speech on this agreement suggested such a course, and I hope that this consultation with industry will develop to a great extent in coming months. 1 suggest that this treaty is a pattern on which Australian trade with other nations in Asia can be expanded. As the honorable member for Barker (Mr. Forbes) this afternoon showed, we made many mistakes in the development of such trade in the 1930's. It is to be hoped that we have learned from those mistakes and that in this new approach to trade with Asia, we shall be able to benefit from the past and make use of the pattern that is already shown in this present agreement. It is important for us that we should develop trade with all nations of Asia, not only for commercial reasons, which are vitally important, but also in the interests of our general relations with those nations. It may be possible, for instance, before long to develop a trade treaty with the federation of Malaya. I, therefore, hope that the Japanese trade agreement will be a pattern for other trade agreements which will be negotiated in the months to come, and that we will be able to increase not only our exports of primary products, but also our exports of manufactured goods to the countries of the Asian mainland.

The House has been told of the advantages to Australia in this treaty and how the export of our main primary products will be expanded during the coming months. There will be advantages not only to the wool-grower and the wheat-grower, but also to those people who are growing barley and sugar. The whole object of this agreement is that there shall be no sudden dis ruption of our export trade, particularly our major exports, and I believe that the Minister is to be congratulated on the way in which he has negotiated these benefits to the primary producer.

I think it is important to see what Australia has given in exchange. First, do not let us exaggerate, as honorable members opposite have done, what actually has been given. There are three main aspects to consider. The first is that imports from Japan have been changed from the general rate of tariff to the intermediate or most favoured nation rate. This represents an average reduction of about Ti per cent. The second aspect is that non-dollar import licence quotas available to people importing from non-dollar countries are now available 100 per cent, in Japan and not only an average of 25 per cent., as heretofore. The third aspect is that Australia has made arrangements to investigate the possibility of allowing and helping Japan to enter into Gatt within the next three years. In essence, we have tried to ensure that there shall be no discrimination against Japanese goods entering the Australian market.

It is in these clauses that the Opposition has found its main objections to the treaty. The questions which I think we should ask are whether the objections are valid and what, in effect, are the safeguards that have been imposed by the Minister. In considering this we should look at the two conditions - first, while import licensing is still in operation, and secondly, when the import licensing regulations have finally been removed altogether. Import licensing is still in existence and therefore if no greater monetary volume of imports is permitted to enter this country, there can only be one effect on Australian industry, and that is that if certain imports from Japan are cheaper, unit for unit, than imports from other places, then possibly, say, one and a half units can come in where only one unit came in before. In this case I suggest that the major sufferer would be the United Kingdom and the actual danger to Australian industry should not be very great. That is while import licensing remains at its present level. There is the danger that importers will put all their eggs into one basket, but it must be remembered that in 1952 some of them made this mistake and suffered for it.

It takes two people to make a contract - the importer in Australia and the exporter in Japan - and I believe that it is in the interests of the Australian importer to spread the imports as much as possible. He should not consider importing only items in category B. There are many Opportunities for importing raw materials and durable goods. Only two or three years ago, large quantities of cement, iron, and steel products were imported from Japan, and it is possible that other durable goods could also be imported in the months to come. Surely it is not likely that the whole of the increase in imports from Japan will be in category B goods. But even if the Australian importers to-day do put all their eggs in one basket and import certain lines which will hurt Australian industry, I suggest that an additional safeguard lies in the fact that the Japanese manufacturers also will realize the facts of life. They realize that by concentrating their exports to this country in specific lines they will be harming not only the whole spirit of the trade agreement but also themselves. They know that those exports can be cut off at a moment's notice. I am sure, therefore, that it is in the best interests of the Japanese industrialists to spread their exports to Australia as widely as possible.

If that second safeguard fails, there is a third one. The Minister himself can take rapid action at a moment's notice. We have also been told, however, that before emergency action becomes necessary the Minister may set up consultation committees, on which will be represented individual industries, which can overlook the applications being made for the import of certain goods. It will be possible for industry to ascertain, at least three months in advance, what goods are likely to be coming to this country, and they may take any necessary action within that time. How different was the situation of industry, say twenty years ago, when an international trade situation developed with practically no warning. By the use of these committees that the Minister has agreed to establish, it will be possible to receive warning of what is to take place three months or more before it actually happens. Plans may be made and action taken to deal with the situation. I believe that these consultation committees will provide the main safeguards for Australian industry.

It is tremendously important that the statistics to be provided by the Government should be as up to date as possible, and I am sure they will be. But it is also im portant that industry itself should take steps to provide reasonably accurate statistics of its production. The Associated Chambers of Manufactures and the various individual sections of the Chambers of Manufactures can do a lot to help themselves and the Government in this respect.

I agree that strict vigilance will be necessary on the part of all concerned, but with the prior warnings that will be available through consultations, and with all the safeguards that I have referred to, there is every prospect that industry will be able to overcome the difficulties that it may encounter in the coming months. The prior warning that may be received from the consultation committees can be transmitted to the Japanese Government. With warnings available to everybody concerned of a situation that may arise three months hence, we will be able to take the necessary action to deal with it. The whole spirit of the agreement will be preserved, I believe, through the various actions that have been suggested by the Minister. Finally, as I have said before, if all else fails and an Australian industry is immediately threatened, rapid action can, and, I am sure, will be taken.

We must all realize that we will benefit considerably if this agreement remains in operation for its full term. It is important that we should not at this stage assert that unemployment is increasing in Australian industry. Nothing is likely to harm an industry more than the assertion that unemployment in that industry is increasing. We should, instead, make use of the chance of this slight breeze of competition that has been referred to. I am sure that increased competition would help many industries to increase their productivity, and so long as the breeze remains a breeze, I believe that it will assist Australian industry. The onus is on the Government to prevent that breeze from turning into a tornado. I feel sure that we can rely on the Government to take all the action necessary to protect Australian industries.

I believe there is no cause for any concern while the import licensing system is still with us, because we can rely on the safeguards that have already been enumerated. If, however, the system of import licensing is removed, I believe that we will need a new series of safeguards. First, I think the time is approaching when we should completely review our tariff-making machine. We should have an authority that can act reasonably quickly. We should make use of the breathing space that we will have while import licensing is still with us to develop the machinery for consultation between the Minister and industry. This will be of great assistance in the development of a workable system when import licensing is removed. I believe that the quota system is not the answer. Instead we should plan for a complete review of our tariff-making machinery.

talk.start.para: - Order! The honorable member's time has expired.

.- I cannot regard this treaty with the same complacency as the honorable member for Fawkner (Mr. Howson). The treaty is designed to encourage trade between Australia and Japan, and one must view it from the standpoint of its meaning to both countries. Japan is a great manufacturing nation. Australia is also a great manufacturing nation. It is true that we produce raw materials, which we export, but it is equally true that substantially more employment is provided in Australia in manufacturing industries than in the production of raw materials. When, therefore, a pact to encourage trade between two manufacturing nations is before us it must receive careful scrutiny, because we have developed our own Australian way of life, and it is necessary for us to see whether the treaty threatens that way of life.

speech.para: The first point which we should consider is the advantages that Japan will receive as a consequence of the treaty. The two main advantages are, first, that Japan will receive the tariff advantages that it would have received had it been a party to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. In other words, it will now be treated on a most favoured nation basis instead of on the general tariff basis. The second advantage is that there will be no further discrimination against Japan in respect of import licensing. The fact that Japan has not had those advantages has acted as a safeguard for Australian industry during the period of import licensing and while the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade has been in operation. So, with the gaining of these advantages by Japan, the safeguards that have protected Australian industry are, in effect, swept away.

I wish to make it clear also that, whilst it is true that in the past Japan had a reputation for manufacturing flimsy and shoddy goods, that is no longer true. Japan is a great manufacturing nation which, due to the technical and financial assistance she has received from America, in addition to the American know-how that has been available to her, is to-day able to produce goods equal to the world's best. Australia also is able to produce goods of high quality, and is an efficient industrial nation. The question is whether under the provisions of the agreement it will be possible for Australian goods to compete in the home market with Japanese imports brought in under the agreement.

A simple analysis of our way of life and the manner in which we have developed our standard of living will indicate the tremendous task that will face Australian industry in holding its own against Japanese competition made possible by the agreement. Let us look at the difference between the working conditions under which goods are produced in Australia and those under which they are produced in Japan. The Commonwealth Statistician states that in the financial year ended 30th June, 1956, the average weekly wage for an Australian adult male was £17 10s. and the hours of labour were 40 a week. In addition to that wage there are overtime payments which are regarded as satisfactory, payment for public holidays, higher rates for shift workers, sick pay, annual leave and long service leave. We in this country have developed a policy that as Australian industry expands and progresses, its employees shall share in that expansion and progress. On the other hand, according to the International Labour Organization's figures, hours of labour in Japan can be up to 60 a week, with the average somewhere about 48i a week, whilst the average weekly wage for males is £5 a week. In many instances the other additional benefits, such as various kinds of leave and extra pay, which are available to Australian workers simply do not exist in Japan. In that country, in cases where there is some additional payment to workers over the ordinary base rate, it is by no means anywhere near the rates fixed in this country.

We simply cannot ignore the facts that the living standards and housing conditions of the workers in Japan are shockingly low compared with those in Australia, and that the Japanese worker does not share in the expansion and progress of Japanese industry as the Australian worker does in the expansion and progress of Australian industry. When these facts are realized and when one appreciates that the advantages which in the past have protected both the Australian manufacturer and the Australian worker are now taken away, it is not hard to see that it is necessary for us to visualise the effect of this agreement. One of the first industries to be affected by the agreement will be the textile industry. That is a well-established industry which employs about 22,000 people in Australia, probably more. It is one of the most decentralized of our industries, because its units are scattered throughout our provincial towns where they provide employment for people who would otherwise be forced to move to the large cities. Millions of pounds of capital are invested in this industry. Since Japan is a great textileproducing nation we have to consider what the effect on the Australian textile industry of the agreement will be. One thing we must bear in mind is that the physical volume of Japanese goods imported under the agreement will be considerably greater than has been entering the country under the import licensing provisions, because of the low prices at which these goods are produced.

I wish to compare for a few moments the conditions in the Japanese textile industry with those in the Australian textile industry in order to emphasize the tremendous threat this trade agreement contains for the Australian textile industry and employment in it. I propose to cite certain figures that were placed before the Tariff Board by Australian employers on the question of the necessity to protect the cotton textile industry. These figures show that of every 100 workers in the Japanese cotton textile industry 80 are females and only twenty are males. In Australia the comparable figures are 52.5 females and 47.5 per cent, males. So, whereas in Japan the preponderance of labour in that industry is female, in Australia the proportions of males and females employed in it are almost equal, with females slightly in the majority.

A comparison of the rates of pay in the two countries gives some startling results. The hourly rate of pay for females in the Japanese cotton textile industry is Hid. The corresponding rate in Australia is 5s. 8d. The male hourly rate in Japan, in that industry, is ls. 8id. and in Australia it is 7s. lOd. The average hourly rate of pay of males and females combined in the Japanese industry is ls. lid., whilst the comparable figure in Australia is 6s. 6d. In other words, the Australian worker is receiving about six times the hourly rate of pay that is received by the Japanese worker. Do not forget that there is, in addition to the difference between the wages element in the cost of production in the two countries, the cost of the provision in Australia of a shorter working week, sick leave, annual leave, long service leave and other industrial conditions.

From the facts and figures I have given the extent to which the Australian textile industry is immediately threatened as a result of this agreement and of the difference between wages and working conditions in the two countries will be immediately evident to the House. The two advantages of most-favoured-nation tariff rates and non-discrimination in respect of licensing, which have been given to Japan, represent a very serious threat indeed to the Australian textile industry. Of course, the textile industry is not the only industry that will be affected. In Japan, manufacturers are advertising to the effect that they are prepared to supply all types of goods anywhere in the world. Naturally, they will seek markets where the purchasing power is greatest. For that reason we find them concentrating on the markets in America, Canada and the United Kingdom. Shortly, they will be concentrating also on Australia and New Zealand, because in those countries the purchasing power is great and the Japanese hope that the best returns will quickly be secured.

In addition to the textile industry, a host of other Australian industries also may be affected, including the industries which manufacture toys, footwear, electrical equipment, electrical goods, hand tools hardware, ceramics, all types of machinery, rubber goods, radios and sewing machines. Goods of high quality may come from Japan to this country, and because of the superior working conditions that operate here, the Australian industries may be unable to compete with the Japanese manufacturers. It is not unreasonable to suppose that, at the end of three years, many Australian industries will be very sick as a result of this treaty.

The safeguards that have been referred to by the Minister are altogether too cumbersome and complicated. As one looks at the treaty, it becomes clear that, when an industry is seriously affected, consultation may take place. Some industries are threatened already, but the Government is not prepared to take action. An industry must be " seriously affected " before action will be taken, and when that happens there will be consultation between the parties. Such consultation could extend over a lengthy period, but the really important question is: What is meant by " seriously affected "? If one factory closes down, does that mean that the industry concerned is seriously affected? Is it necessary for factories to close down entirely, or will they be deemed to be seriously affected if they are working half time, or with only half their normal number of employees? The more one thinks of these safeguards, of which honorable members opposite have spoken with such complacency, the more one appreciates the difficulty of determining the meaning of " serious " in this connexion and how long it may be before action is taken. I point out that while a serious position was developing in an industry, the Australian market could be flooded with Japanese goods, so that when the action was taken it might be too late for the industry to be restored to its former position.

Similar pacts have been made with other countries - with what result? Because of the rapid importation of Japanese goods into the United States eventually a quota system had to be devised. In Canada, Japanese goods were imported at a terrific rate, with the result that the Canadian textile industry is now struggling to prevent itself from being strangled. We have seen the importation of Japanese goods into Africa, a market that once belonged to the United Kingdom and which, in the last two years, has been lost to it altogether. We know that those things are going on. The evidence of them is before this House and the people of Australia to-day; yet, here we are talking about making a pact of this kind! It seems to me that when action is taken by the Government because of the serious position that is bound to develop in various industries, it will be too late, because the unemployment which has been increasing so noticeably in Australia during the last nine or twelve months will have become very much greater. My own thought is that Japanese purchases of our wool, both this year and next year, will be on a considerably smaller scale than they were in the past, because the Japanese have been able to establish, from a bargaining standpoint, the fact that the gap in the trade between the two countries is already too great. 1 conclude by saying that the more one studies the pact the more one is convinced that it is a serious threat to Australian industry. The House should indicate in a most emphatic manner that it will have none of it. In these days of increasing unemployment it is folly of the worst kind to open the door to destruction of Australian industries and the Australian way of life by entering into a pact of this kind.

talk.start.para: .- I rise to give my support to this new agreement on commerce between the Commonwealth of Australia and Japan for the next three years. The honorable member for Bendigo (Mr. Clarey) dwelt at some length on the possible effects of increased Japanese exports of a cheap kind of textile upon the Australian textile industry, which is an established industry, and during the course of my speech I shall make some comment on the situation as I see it, or perhaps I should say, as I foresee it. I want to say something about the reference of the honorable member for Bendigo to the South African textile market which, he said, had been gained by Japan during the last few years that she had had access to it, at the expense of the United Kingdom. I think that that was an inaccurate statement.
- I said " African ", not " South African ".

- If the honorable member had been referring to South Africa, where one might imagine that cheap Japanese textiles would be attractive, let me inform him that the experience has been of entirely the opposite kind. I cannot, of course, speak of the whole of the African market, which is very wide and variable, but South Africa no doubt would account for a very good proportion of the total African market. There is in South Africa no quota system, no limitation of the quantity of goods that may come into the country. There are no import restrictions such as we have in Australia. Certainly, when the Japanese goods were first admitted there was an enthusiasm for them, but it faded after the first twelve months, and now Japanese textiles hold only a very small percentage of the total South African market.

speech.para: This agreement provides distinct advantages for both countries. In moving about amongst the people and the merchants of Melbourne, my home city, it has seemed to me that there is wide misunderstanding in the public mind about this agreement, not so much amongst the merchants who are familiar with its details and its possible effects, as amongst the people generally, many of whom seem to think that Japan will enjoy some special privilege not enjoyed by other countries from which we import. This is entirely erroneous. Indeed, Japan is the only country in the world against which we have exercised, until now, a most severe discrimination in our import policy. This agreement does away wilh that discrimination and places Japan in the same category as all other foreign countries.

It has always been a source of wonder to me that Communist countries and other for'mer enemy countries have enjoyed a great advantage over Japan in the Australian market. The iron curtain countries such as Yugoslavia, Roumania, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Bulgaria, Germany, both West and East, Poland, Italy, Austria, Soviet Russia and red China, all have enjoyed this advantage over Japan in our import policy, both in the quantity of goods that they can export to Australia and in our tariff imposts, in spite of the fact that Japan is our second largest customer. This agreement now places Japan on the same basis as the countries that I have mentioned and all other foreign countries.

The Minister for Labour and National Service (Mr. Harold Holt) made a very good point in speaking in this debate recently when he pointed out that the Opposition has constantly advocated increased trade with red China to which we export only a very small percentage of our trade. It seems that the Opposition is prepared to promote trade with Communist China on an unrestricted basis but would continue the severe restrictions on trade with democratic Japan which is our second best customer.

The precise details of this agreement have been discussed at length during the course of this debate and have been clearly explained to the House by the Minister for Trade (Mr. McEwen). Suffice for me to give, in the briefest form, a summary of the advantages to Australia. This agreement protects our export trade with Japan in wool, wheat and flour and protects other products from discrimination by Japan in her tariff and quota restrictions. It opens up most attractive new market opportunities for wheat, sugar, and many other products. Opposition criticism, which we heard this evening and last Thursday, appeared to me to ignore the great benefits to Australia and the contributions which the agreement makes to our overseas trading position and which it will make, therefore, to our balance of payments in our general international trade. Without such guarantees by Japan concerning discrimination against Australia's products, we have been quite unable to make predictions with anything like the accuracy necessary in our forward national planning.

On the other hand this agreement provides that the Japanese will have the same basis of trading with us in future as do other foreign countries, both in licensing and in tariff treatment. In order to protect those Australian secondary industries which may be seriously affected by an influx of cheaper Japanese goods, important protective provisions have been written into the agreement. As the Minister for Trade has explained, the Japanese Government recognizes the importance of restraining imports so that they do not reach a level where serious injury is caused or threatened to any Australian industry. I shall have something to say upon this matter of restraint a little later. If, in the opinion of the Australian Government, this restraint at the Japanese end is ineffective and the position warrants it, the Government is free, in the terms of the agreement, to impose emergency duties or quantitative restrictions against the Japanese goods concerned without delay.

Concern has been expressed by a number of Australian secondary industries that the agreement will enable our manufacturers to be under-sold. I wish to devote some brief remarks to the textile industry because it is this industry - particularly the woollen and worsted manufacturers - which has been the most vociferous in its opposition to the agreement. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr. Evatt) concentrated upon this industry in his rather tedious and unconvincing speech. Firstly, let me say something about cotton textiles, in the main, printed cottons. Perhaps I should explain that, prior to this agreement, importers held licences for, shall we say, 100 units. Twenty-five of these units could be used to import Japanese cottons and the balance of 75 units for imports from other sterling countries. This agreement now makes it possible for importers to devote the whole 100 units to imports from Japan if they so desire. Also, under existing tariff schedules, importers of Japanese cottons have been paying a duty of 3?d. a yard, whereas the duty on similar piece goods from other foreign countries has been 2d. a yard. This agreement bring Japan into line with all other foreign countries and her cotton piece goods will now be dutiable at 2d. a yard.

A considerable quantity of cottons and rayons presently come to Australia from the United Kingdom, Holland and Germany, but quantities are also coming from Czechslovakia, Hungary and Poland. Imports from Yugoslavia are small but growing, and even Roumania is coming into the picture. Italy, of course, is another country from which we import a considerable quantity of cotton piece goods. The imports of cottons from Holland and Germany have grown tremendously at the expense, mainly, of the United Kingdom.

I am informed by a number of importers and, from my own experience, I would say that continental printed cottons, particularly the Dutch and German, have better designs and are cheaper than the British equivalent and have stolen much of the United Kingdom's trade throughout the world. Indeed, in the cheaper bracket of cottons and rayons I do not think it is realized, particularly in this House, that many other countries are now offering full competition to Japan. I should like to suggest to the House that the country which may well become, in a relatively short time, the dominant country in the manufacture of cotton textiles, is Communist China. She founded her textile industry on machinery from Russia and adapted it and improved it to the point at which she is now able to undersell Japan in the world market for cotton textiles. In silks, of course, red China can beat the world, including Japan.

The cotton textile printing industry in Australia, I have always felt, is not firmly based. The companies which are engaged in printing cottons import the basic material, grey cloth as it is called, almost duty free, mainly from Japan, and print and finish that material here. If the grey cloth were woven in Australia then my attitude to the cotton textile printing industry would, of course, be entirely different. Rayons printed in Australia are already heavily protected by our tariff schedules. The foreign rayons are dutiable at ls. 8id. a yard and Japanese rayons, now dutiable at the same figure, were formerly dutiable at 2s. Hd. a yard. I feel that the reduction in duty on Japanese printed cottons should not unduly affect the printers here because the price of Japanese materials, even with the operation of the higher duty of 3?d. a yard, which has been reduced to 2d., was considerably lower than that of cottons printed in Australia.

With regard to the woollen textile industry, it is difficult to understand why our manufacturers are displaying such a sensitive reaction to this agreement. Unlike cottons, rayons and many other items, woollen textiles from Japan have not been the subject of discrimination since 1954; also, this agreement does not vary significantly the tariff duties which have been applied to woollens during the last three years. So, from the point of view of both quantity and tariff, there is very little change in the conditions which have obtained since 1954. No one, having examined the figures, could say that the woollen textile industry in Australia has suffered from imports from Japan in that time. As the Minister pointed out, the imports from Japan in woollen yarns, blankets and piece goods have been so small as to be inconsiderable. Why, with conditions almost unchanged, should we find a sudden burst of imports of these goods from Japan?

Mr. Speaker, I am very proud and J should think that every Australian is of our Australian woollen textile industry. li has grown into a major industry. It is efficient and produces goods of excellent quality. I suppose that I could truthfully say that I am a protectionist where protection can be justifiably and intelligently applied. This industry is one, which, in its early days, was nurtured under stringent protective measures. It has proved itself completely. I am not of the opinion that it need be unduly disturbed by the terms of this agreement. However, I do feel that there is a threat to made-up woollen goods such as knitted items of wearing apparel, and similar types of goods. Imports of these will have to be watched carefully. The same might apply to certain items of clothing made of cotton.

No one could deny the possibility that certain industries will be threatened by Japanese imports and that they will need protection through appropriate action taken as provided for in the agreement. I am sure that industries which feel concerned will be re-assured by the Minister's offer of industry consultation with himself and officials of the Department of Trade. In addition the Minister told us that the Government proposes to establish a . special advisory authority to make recommendations to the Minister responsible for the protection of Australian industries. For myself, I was very pleased to hear him say that he proposed to invite the chambers of commerce and chambers of manufactures to discuss with him the form which this advisory authority should take.

I mentioned earlier thai Japan recognized the necessity for restraint in her exports to Australia where these could menace Australian industry. I have seen correspondence within the last few days which provides positive proof that, over the whole textile field, Japanese exporters are refusing to quote our importers because they have reached the quantitative restriction imposed by their Government. This would indicate that Japan is watching closely her commitments under this agreement. There is proof also that not only the quantity is carefully checked but the price structure also.

Mr. Speaker, this agreement does not provide for any increase in our total imports. It allows our importers to buy less from other countries and more from Japan if they wish to do so. In no way whatsoever is the preferred position of the United Kingdom in the Australian market altered; that remains quite unchanged. I say again that this trade treaty does away with an ugly, unhealthy discrimination which was directed at only one country in the world - Japan - which is the second largest buyer in the world of Australian products. Trade between nations is, in these days, full of complexities, but one of the first principles to be observed is that such trade is a two-way business. I am sure that Australia will gain the benefits provided for in this agreement without sacrificing the interests of Australian industry.
